M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1D.proposition: 3 **Lynn District Court** has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 231, § 1D as this is a tort case involving damages well under the monetary limit for district court jurisdiction.

Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 143,.raw_text: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 143, § 3J (requiring public and residential buildings to comply with fire safety provisions regarding smoke detectors).
Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 143,.proposition: - Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 143, § 3J (requiring public and residential buildings to comply with fire safety provisions regarding smoke detectors).

Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 229,.raw_text: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 229, § 2 (establishing a duty of care to prevent harmful outcomes caused by negligence).
Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 229,.proposition: - Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 229, § 2 (establishing a duty of care to prevent harmful outcomes caused by negligence).

**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).raw_text: **Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (discussing landlord liability for dangerous conditions on premises that they control).
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: - **Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (discussing landlord liability for dangerous conditions on premises that they control).
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The case directly addresses a homeowner/landowner’s duty regarding dangerous conditions—in particular, firearms—kept on premises she owns and controls. The SJC holds that a homeowner who allows guns to be stored on her property and grants unsupervised access to a person known to be violent and mentally unstable owes a duty of reasonable care to ensure those guns are properly secured, grounding that duty in both foreseeability and premises-control concepts. This aligns with the proposition that Jupin discusses landlord (or landowner) liability for dangerous conditions on premises under their control.
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage.”

**Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 417 Mass..raw_text: **Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 417 Mass. 159 (1994) (imposing a duty of ordinary care on landlords with respect to common areas).
**Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 417 Mass..proposition: - **Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 417 Mass. 159 (1994) (imposing a duty of ordinary care on landlords with respect to common areas).
**Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 417 Mass..support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion concerns ERISA preemption of state common-law misrepresentation claims related to employee benefit plans. It does not address landlord-tenant law, common areas, or any duty of care owed by landlords. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth. imposed a duty of ordinary care on landlords with respect to common areas; the citation is to a completely different subject matter.
**Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth.**, 417 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “When Congress enacted the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), 29 U.S.C. §§ 1001-1461 (1988), it included an expansive provision preempting any State laws which ‘relate to’ an employee benefits plan. The question presented by this case is whether a claim that an employer’s misrepresentation that an employee would be provided with long-term disability benefits during the six months following his termination sufficiently ‘relates to’ an employee benefit plan so as to be preempted by ERISA.”

**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..raw_text: **Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.**, 388 Mass. 342, 347 (1983) (defining causation in a negligence claim).
**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..proposition: - **Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.**, 388 Mass. 342, 347 (1983) (defining causation in a negligence claim).
**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..case_name: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.
**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..support_reasoning: The proposition is that Correia v. Firestone is cited for defining causation in a negligence claim. In answering Question Two, the court expressly states the basic causation requirement in negligence—plaintiff must prove defendant’s breach proximately caused the injury—and explains when another party’s negligence is material only if it is the sole proximate cause. This passage directly articulates the causation standard in Massachusetts negligence law, so the citation is accurate for that proposition.
**Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co..relevant_excerpt: “It is elemental that a plaintiff may recover from a defendant in negligence only if he proves that the defendant’s breach of a duty of care owed to the plaintiff proximately caused the plaintiff’s injuries. Payton v. Abbott Labs., 386 Mass. 540, 548 (1982). … The problem, of course, is that any negligence of Concord Steel is not material to the issue of Firestone’s liability unless Concord Steel’s negligence, either standing alone or combined with the negligence of Correia, was the sole proximate cause of Correia’s injuries.”

**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.raw_text: **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980) (holding landlords responsible for maintaining safe conditions in common areas).
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.proposition: - **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 169 (1980) (holding landlords responsible for maintaining safe conditions in common areas).
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss landlord responsibility for maintaining safe conditions, but its key doctrinal move is to extend a landlord’s duty of reasonable care to *all areas of the rented premises*, not just common areas under the landlord’s control. The portion cited at page 169 announces a general negligence standard for landlords as to defects on leased premises; common-area duties had already been recognized in earlier cases like Lindsey and King and are described as background. Thus, the case is broader than and not specifically a holding limited to common areas, so the proposition as phrased is inaccurate.
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.relevant_excerpt: “Today, we do away with the ancient law that bars a tenant’s guest from recovering compensation from a landlord for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant. … Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.”

**Lindsey v. Massios**, 372 Mass. 79, 84.raw_text: **Lindsey v. Massios**, 372 Mass. 79, 84 (1977) (establishing premises liability for landlords).
**Lindsey v. Massios**, 372 Mass. 79, 84.proposition: - **Lindsey v. Massios**, 372 Mass. 79, 84 (1977) (establishing premises liability for landlords).
**Lindsey v. Massios**, 372 Mass. 79, 84.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly holds that a landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common areas to all lawful visitors, including tenants’ guests, and overrules the prior, more limited common-law rule. This is a clear statement of premises liability for landlords toward lawful visitors, based on a duty of reasonable care and the relevance of safety statute violations as evidence of negligence. Thus the case properly stands for establishing (and broadening) premises liability for landlords in Massachusetts.
**Lindsey v. Massios**, 372 Mass. 79, 84.relevant_excerpt: "Therefore, we no longer follow the common law rule that a landlord owes to his tenants’ visitors the same duty he owes to his tenants concerning the maintenance of common passageways in his control. The landowner’s duty of reasonable care in maintaining property he controls extends to all lawful visitors on his premises, including the lawful visitors of his tenants."

**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 70.raw_text: **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (imposing a general duty of reasonable care toward tenants).
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 70.proposition: - **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (imposing a general duty of reasonable care toward tenants).
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 70.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurrence by Justice Kaplan criticizing the continued significance of the trespasser category; it does not itself discuss or formulate a general duty of reasonable care toward tenants. While the full Mounsey opinion is known for imposing a general duty of reasonable care toward lawful visitors (including tenants), that specific proposition is not reflected in this passage. Thus, based solely on the quoted text, the opinion segment does not support the stated proposition.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693, 70.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

**King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 80 Mass..raw_text: **King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 700, 704 (2011) (reaffirming landlord obligations to ensure safe passageways).
**King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 80 Mass..proposition: - **King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 700, 704 (2011) (reaffirming landlord obligations to ensure safe passageways).
**King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 80 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial lease/guaranty and mitigation-of-damages case; it does not involve landlord‑tenant tort duties, common‑area safety, or obligations to maintain safe passageways for tenants or invitees. The court instead addresses enforceability of a rent acceleration clause and whether mitigation is relevant when such a liquidated damages provision exists. Therefore, citing this case for a proposition about landlord obligations to ensure safe passageways misstates its holding and context.
**King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 80 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "The lease provided that the tenant, at his sole cost and expense, would keep and maintain the premises, equipment, pipes, plumbing, wires, glass, building, and surrounding grounds in good repair. On the other hand, the lease provided that the 'Landlord shall be responsible, at Landlord’s sole cost and expense, to make all exterior structural repairs to the building and repairs to the parking lot which are reasonably necessary to keep the same in good repair, order and condition'…"
